summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to JPMorgan Chase Bank, demanding extensive financial records for an account holder for the period from January 1, 2019 onward. The subpoena is related to an investigation into alleged violations of federal statutes including bribery, conspiracy, false statements, and obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued and signed the grand jury subpoena to JPMorgan Chase Bank as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: The subpoena commands JPMorgan Chase Bank to appear before the grand jury at the U.S. Courthouse in New York to testify and produce records.

events.title: Subpoena Issuance
events.description: The grand jury subpoena was issued and dated, demanding financial records from JPMorgan Chase Bank.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Manhattan, New York, NY
JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. National Subpoena Processing Center, 7610W Washington Street, Indianapolis, IN 46231
U.S. Attorney's Office, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
U.S. Attorney's Office - SDNY Accounts Payable, 86 Chambers Street, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The subpoena targets JPMorgan Chase Bank for records related to a specific account holder, seeking documents from January 1, 2019, onward.

The investigation involves alleged violations of federal statutes including 18 U.S.C. §§ 201 (bribery), 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), 1346 (honest services fraud), 1519 (obstruction), and 2 (aiding and abetting).
The requested records are extensive, including account opening documents, statements, wire transfers, check images, credit card records, and customer contact information.
The document includes detailed technical instructions for the electronic production of financial data in spreadsheet and PDF formats.

The subpoena references a procedure for the bank to request reimbursement for costs under the Right to Financial Privacy Act, but notes costs are not reimbursable for records of corporations or large partnerships.
